Description: Hollow-cast, copper alloy rectangular box surmounted by two solid-cast figures lying side by side representing Atum in a composite shape: human-head wearing Atef crown with a long beard and tripartite wig; body combining raised cobra/uraeus and eel for lower part of body; transition from eel to uraeus supported behind by an ostrich feather; two double rings for suspension on opposite corners at either end of top of case; figures on a simple empty base (or les likely votive box?); corroded; complete.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Town (Naukratis), House of 'cache of bronzes'
Curator's comments: This piece was found with a large group of copper alloy finds in a house located to the south of the town (Petrie 1886, 41). The context of discovery can be dated around the end of the 5th-beginning of the 4th century BC (Masson 2015). The composite figure represents the solar god and demiurge Atum (Weiss 2012, 178-180). This deity is very well-represented at Naukratis, particularly in the category of votive box and especially in the shape of lizard, snake and eel (Masson forthcoming b). This specimen belongs to the type 87 in the typology of figure bronzes by K. Weiss (Weiss 2012, 656-657, Taf. 26a-c, Typ 87). The god usually wears a double-crown for type 87 (Weiss 2012, 178-180). Another human-headed cobra bronze figure was discovered in Naukratis: BM 1885,1101.105. Petrie, W. M. F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884-5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Masson, A. 2015, ‘Cult and Trade. A reflexion on Egyptian metal offerings from Naukratis’, in D. Robinson and F. Goddio (eds), Thonis Heracleion in Context, Oxford Centre for Maritime Archaeology Monograph 8, Oxford, 71-88. Masson, A. forthcoming b, ‘Naukratis: Egyptian offerings in context’, in M. Bergeron and A. Masson (eds), Naukratis in Context: Cults, Sanctuaries and Offerings, Proceedings of the second Naukratis workshop, held at the British Museum 22nd – 23rd June 2013. Weiss, K. 2012, Ägyptische Tier- und Götterbronzen aus Unterägypten: Untersuchungen zu Typus, Ikonographie und Funktion sowie der Bedeutung innerhalb der Kulturkontakte zu Griechenland, Ägypten und Altes Testament 81.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (MB.181) (phase 2)
